Hopkins University.

DEBATING SCHEDULE WILL
BE BRILLIANT
According to Lawrence D. Willison, president of the Debating
Council, a highly interesting
schedule is being arranged for the
Varsity Debating Team. The Annual Triangular Debate with University of North Carolina and
Washington and Lee will be as in
previous years the most important
event of the debating season and
closely approaching it in point of
interest will be the dual meets
with the University of Richmond
and the University of Virginia.
It is hoped by those in charge
that the University of Maryland
will be on the schedule as the rivalry between State and the Blue
Jays is always .strong. Last year
Maryland had no team but efforts
are being made to form one at
least in time to meet the Hopkins
debaters in a dual argument.
Willison is trying to excite
more interest among the "undergrads" and hopes to increase attendance at the debates. Social
features of this year's clashes will
include dancing with the Blue Jay
Six and the serving of refreshments.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 7, 1924

REGULATION NUMBER ONE
The fact that all the leading institutions of higher learning perireshman regulations to exist affords strong presumption that
they are regarded with favor and that their influence is for good
rather than for evil. Yet their value is. questioned by ninety-nine
per cent of the freshmen in every university. In brief, for the benefit of those doubting yearlings, freshman regulations develop discipline, teach college tradition, make necessary class organization,
promote college allegiance, arouse ambition, and afford opportunity
for many instances of mutual helpfulness.
It is obvious, even to freshmen, that all the regulations are not
intended for disciplinary purposes or humiliation of the first year
men. Regulation Number One is the one which affords opportunity
for mutual helpfulness. On the one hand the freshman, being required to participate in some activity, serves his Alma Mater, while
in "learning the ropes" he is aided and guided by experienced upperclassmen. This rule, intended to equip the "frosh" for his part in the
life of Johns Hopkins, has done much to put Hopkins activities on
a sound footing. Through its enforcement much hidden ability and
talent is uncovered. No doubt interesting statistics might be compiled from facts gathered from present college leaders showing the
rise of the majority during their four years in college.
While participation in activities is recognized as advantageous,
it is likewise clearly seen that over indulgence is disadvantageous
and in some cases even harmful. It should be remembered at all
times that pursuit of knowledge is the real reason for coming to college and not to engage solely in activities. The News-Letter, therefore, in its paternal capacity, would advise the freshman in colloquial
terms "not to bite off more than he can chew."
OPPORTUNITY
A former editor of the News-Letter, on turning over the quill
to his successor, was heard to remark: "I would not substitute the
experience gained through my work in college journalism fOr any
three courses offered in the curriculum." A statement of this kind
is proof of the value of News-Letter work. College newspaper work
is undoubtedly the broadest in scope of any activity, for in reporting
news one is brought into contact with faculty members, university
officials; campus leaders, and the entire student body.
In . )ecoming a candidate for the News-Letter, a freshman is
offered tie opportunity of getting acquainted with college life. Aside
from the feeling of service to Johns Hopkins, there is a material
:reward offered. The Varsity Seal, a miniature reproduction in gold
of the University seal, is given for faithful and consistent work in
non-athletic activities. The Seal corresponds to the Varsity "H."
Candidates will be welcomed in the News-Letter Office today at
12:30.
The News-Letter regrets to announce the resignation of Harold S. Goodwin, '26, from the edi tonal staff.

ACIll

As a football player
he's a good poet
E T'S admit that all men are not born for
gridiron honors, just as all men are not
born poets.
You can admire a man's grit for plugging
away at the thing that comes hardest to him.
He does derive benefit in developing himself
where he is weakest. But to achieve real success
it is only common wisdom to pick out the line
for which you have a natural aptitude—and go
to it.
Particularly if you are a freshman it may be
useful to remind you of this principle, because
it can help you start off on the right foot in both
your campus activities and your college courses.
If your fingers love the feel of a pencil, why
not obey that impulse and come out for the
publications? You can serve Alma Mater and
yourself better as a first-class editor than a thirdclass halfback.
Similarly, when it comes to electing your college courses,you will be happier and more efficient if you choose in accordance with your
natural aptitude.
The world needs many types of men. Find
your line, and your college course will be a preparation for a greater success.

BROWN ELECTED PRESIDENT OF COTILLON
CLUB
"Eddie" Brown, active in Cotillion Club circles during the last
scholastic year, was chosen president of the society at the regular
meeting last week. He succeeds
W. Carville Gardner, under whose
leadership the club enjoyed one of
the most succesful years in its history.

RED PREDOMINATES IN THE
FIRST SOPH-FROSH
SCRAP
Red! Red was the color predominating. No doubt about it. The
Frosh and Sophs both saw red,
there was a plentiful besprinkling
of the red life fluid, proceeding
from the olfactory organs of
numerous combatants, and topping
the whole proceeding was the fiery
red head of one of the most pugnacious Freshmen that ever trod
the paths of Homewood.
This particular chap would persist in walking on the sacred lawns,
in spite of President Goodnow's
-straight line admonition," in spite
of certain well-known regulations,
and in spite of the objections of
certain gentlemen known generically as the "wise fools." And when
he walked forward, his Freshmen
compatriots saw red, both figuratively and literally, stepped in where
angels feared to tread (no insinuations meant), and were soundly
paddled for their pains by the aforementioned -wise-fool- Sophs.
It was a great battle while it lasted. Rolling, scratching, yelling
masses of humanity fought hard
and loyally for the honor of their
respective classes. Standing on the
:fide-lines, Juniors, but a space removed from such squabbles, cheered
for the Freshmen, urged the battles on, and laughed long and heartily; they knew that their own fighting days were o'er, hence no forebodings prevented their mirth from.
reaching its highest pitch. Seniors
yawned lazily, or smiled cynically,
in order to maintain their legened
dignity, although in reality they enjoyed the battle as much as any one
else. Even certain dignified professors, long known for their unperturable tranquillity in the face
of all student pranks, were seen gingerly poking their heads forth from
office windows, and as quickly withdrawing them. Their reputation
had to be maintained. Yes, this
was a real fight.
The Frosh seemed to have the
edge. Out numbering the Sophs
almost two to one, they showed
their valor in true Hopkins fashion.
Besides, did they not have the redheaded leader to make them see red;
did not their respective countenances show red with blood, and
wasn't that tingling sensation induced by paddles a most reddening
matter? The Sophs were up against
too much red, in this the first battle of the year. They tried to believe that it was green. green Frosh,
but they either were color-blind, or
determined to avoid facts. There
was too much red for the Sophs.

SOPHS MAKE NOMINATIONS
FOR STUDENT COUNCIL
Nominations for student council
representative were made by the
sophomore class at its first meeting of the year. on Tuesday, September 30. Those named were
Meredith, Cleaveland, Harwood,
Frantz, Niner, and Passano. The
election will be held at the next

Sailing West to India
€53INCE the days of Christopher Columbus men have felt
the call to ((sail due west to find
India." In an organization like
Westinghouse, such pioneering
spirits find happy haven as research engineers. Their every
thought is a question—every
energy bent to discover new
and more effective answers to
baffling problems.
Immediately Westinghouse
began to build alternating current machines of high voltages,
for example, the problem of
insulation became acute. For
thirty-five years high voltages
and insulation have formed an
endless chain of problems. As
voltages have been increased,
improved insulation has been
demanded. As insulation has

been bettered, voltages have
been still further increased.
One striking contribution of
Westinghouse research engineers has been the perfection
of an entirely new insulation
material— Micarta. Possessing
many of the qualities of metal,
paper,fiber, mica,gum,rubber,
Micarta differs in radical respect from all of these.
It serves industry indirectly
as improved insulation material, and also directly because
of superiorities when used for
gears, propeller blades, and
the like.
Only the imagination can
set a limit on the field for the
research engineer—or for an
organization that centers
around him.

DEBATING SCHEDULE WILL
BE BRILLIANT
According to Lawrence D. Willison, president of the Debating
Council, a highly interesting
schedule is being arranged for the
Varsity Debating Team. The Annual Triangular Debate with University of North Carolina and
Washington and Lee will be as in
previous years the most important
event of the debating season and
closely approaching it in point of
interest will be the dual meets
with the University of Richmond
and the University of Virginia.
It is hoped by those in charge
that the University of Maryland
will be on the schedule as the rivalry between State and the Blue
Jays is always .strong. Last year
Maryland had no team but efforts
are being made to form one at
least in time to meet the Hopkins
debaters in a dual argument.
Willison is trying to excite
more interest among the "undergrads" and hopes to increase attendance at the debates. Social
features of this year's clashes will
include dancing with the Blue Jay
Six and the serving of refreshments.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 7, 1924

REGULATION NUMBER ONE
The fact that all the leading institutions of higher learning perireshman regulations to exist affords strong presumption that
they are regarded with favor and that their influence is for good
rather than for evil. Yet their value is. questioned by ninety-nine
per cent of the freshmen in every university. In brief, for the benefit of those doubting yearlings, freshman regulations develop discipline, teach college tradition, make necessary class organization,
promote college allegiance, arouse ambition, and afford opportunity
for many instances of mutual helpfulness.
It is obvious, even to freshmen, that all the regulations are not
intended for disciplinary purposes or humiliation of the first year
men. Regulation Number One is the one which affords opportunity
for mutual helpfulness. On the one hand the freshman, being required to participate in some activity, serves his Alma Mater, while
in "learning the ropes" he is aided and guided by experienced upperclassmen. This rule, intended to equip the "frosh" for his part in the
life of Johns Hopkins, has done much to put Hopkins activities on
a sound footing. Through its enforcement much hidden ability and
talent is uncovered. No doubt interesting statistics might be compiled from facts gathered from present college leaders showing the
rise of the majority during their four years in college.
While participation in activities is recognized as advantageous,
it is likewise clearly seen that over indulgence is disadvantageous
and in some cases even harmful. It should be remembered at all
times that pursuit of knowledge is the real reason for coming to college and not to engage solely in activities. The News-Letter, therefore, in its paternal capacity, would advise the freshman in colloquial
terms "not to bite off more than he can chew."
OPPORTUNITY
A former editor of the News-Letter, on turning over the quill
to his successor, was heard to remark: "I would not substitute the
experience gained through my work in college journalism fOr any
three courses offered in the curriculum." A statement of this kind
is proof of the value of News-Letter work. College newspaper work
is undoubtedly the broadest in scope of any activity, for in reporting
news one is brought into contact with faculty members, university
officials; campus leaders, and the entire student body.
In . )ecoming a candidate for the News-Letter, a freshman is
offered tie opportunity of getting acquainted with college life. Aside
from the feeling of service to Johns Hopkins, there is a material
:reward offered. The Varsity Seal, a miniature reproduction in gold
of the University seal, is given for faithful and consistent work in
non-athletic activities. The Seal corresponds to the Varsity "H."
Candidates will be welcomed in the News-Letter Office today at
12:30.

ACIll

As a football player
he's a good poet
E T'S admit that all men are not born for
gridiron honors, just as all men are not
born poets.
You can admire a man's grit for plugging
away at the thing that comes hardest to him.
He does derive benefit in developing himself
where he is weakest. But to achieve real success
it is only common wisdom to pick out the line
for which you have a natural aptitude—and go
to it.
Particularly if you are a freshman it may be
useful to remind you of this principle, because
it can help you start off on the right foot in both
your campus activities and your college courses.
If your fingers love the feel of a pencil, why
not obey that impulse and come out for the
publications? You can serve Alma Mater and
yourself better as a first-class editor than a thirdclass halfback.
Similarly, when it comes to electing your college courses,you will be happier and more efficient if you choose in accordance with your
natural aptitude.
The world needs many types of men. Find
your line, and your college course will be a preparation for a greater success.

RED PREDOMINATES IN THE
FIRST SOPH-FROSH
SCRAP
Red! Red was the color predominating. No doubt about it. The
Frosh and Sophs both saw red,
there was a plentiful besprinkling
of the red life fluid, proceeding
from the olfactory organs of
numerous combatants, and topping
the whole proceeding was the fiery
red head of one of the most pugnacious Freshmen that ever trod
the paths of Homewood.
This particular chap would persist in walking on the sacred lawns,
in spite of President Goodnow's
-straight line admonition," in spite
of certain well-known regulations,
and in spite of the objections of
certain gentlemen known generically as the "wise fools." And when
he walked forward, his Freshmen
compatriots saw red, both figuratively and literally, stepped in where
angels feared to tread (no insinuations meant), and were soundly
paddled for their pains by the aforementioned -wise-fool- Sophs.
It was a great battle while it lasted. Rolling, scratching, yelling
masses of humanity fought hard
and loyally for the honor of their
respective classes. Standing on the
:fide-lines, Juniors, but a space removed from such squabbles, cheered
for the Freshmen, urged the battles on, and laughed long and heartily; they knew that their own fighting days were o'er, hence no forebodings prevented their mirth from.
reaching its highest pitch. Seniors
yawned lazily, or smiled cynically,
in order to maintain their legened
dignity, although in reality they enjoyed the battle as much as any one
else. Even certain dignified professors, long known for their unperturable tranquillity in the face
of all student pranks, were seen gingerly poking their heads forth from
office windows, and as quickly withdrawing them. Their reputation
had to be maintained. Yes, this
was a real fight.
The Frosh seemed to have the
edge. Out numbering the Sophs
almost two to one, they showed
their valor in true Hopkins fashion.
Besides, did they not have the redheaded leader to make them see red;
did not their respective countenances show red with blood, and
wasn't that tingling sensation induced by paddles a most reddening
matter? The Sophs were up against
too much red, in this the first battle of the year. They tried to believe that it was green. green Frosh,
but they either were color-blind, or
determined to avoid facts. There
was too much red for the Sophs.

SOPHS MAKE NOMINATIONS
FOR STUDENT COUNCIL
Nominations for student council
representative were made by the
sophomore class at its first meeting of the year. on Tuesday, September 30. Those named were
Meredith, Cleaveland, Harwood,
Frantz, Niner, and Passano. The
election will be held at the next

Sailing West to India
€53INCE the days of Christopher Columbus men have felt
the call to ((sail due west to find
India." In an organization like
Westinghouse, such pioneering
spirits find happy haven as research engineers. Their every
thought is a question—every
energy bent to discover new
and more effective answers to
baffling problems.
Immediately Westinghouse
began to build alternating current machines of high voltages,
for example, the problem of
insulation became acute. For
thirty-five years high voltages
and insulation have formed an
endless chain of problems. As
voltages have been increased,
improved insulation has been
demanded. As insulation has

been bettered, voltages have
been still further increased.
One striking contribution of
Westinghouse research engineers has been the perfection
of an entirely new insulation
material— Micarta. Possessing
many of the qualities of metal,
paper,fiber, mica,gum,rubber,
Micarta differs in radical respect from all of these.
It serves industry indirectly
as improved insulation material, and also directly because
of superiorities when used for
gears, propeller blades, and
the like.
Only the imagination can
set a limit on the field for the
research engineer—or for an
organization that centers
around him.
